the staff and have in fact subcontracted the distribution of kines. Many prefer to
deal directly through companies and there are various other individual consider¬
ations. The Center wants to stay out of the contracting and detail business, I
believe and do just planning.
Daniel: We have a kine processor on Campus but the quality isn’t uniform
enough or consistent. To get this consistency through the Center would be practical
and economical. This is one area the Center could really help in. It seems the
time has come, with present costs for film, that we should build up our TV library
laboratory. The Center doesn’t seem to be gathering in material. We need to cut
cost, and get uniform quality, and be able to run through films and get good shows
that aren't necessarily prepared by the station itself.
Skornia: I don't think the Center should get into the operational end.
Neither the NAEB nor the Center want to compete with legitimate business. And we
have to count on our members to add to the present films and kines. Actually, these
questions could best be answered by the Center.
Gunn; The Center has been forced to lend some operational aid because if a
lab ruins a kine, the Center is hurt, for it gives the money originally. There
should be some standard process so high investment in a kine isn't lost. The
Center doesn't even have information on what are good labs and what aren't.
Skornia: I think we'd better put this on the agenda of the NAEB Advisory
Committee to the Center, which meets next at Columbus. Afraid we are not competent
or authorized to decide such things-—.
Question: Mr. Wheatley, why do you have such a short program time?
Wheatley: These hours represent what we think we can do well enough. It is
a question of what the community expects and is suited to the needs of the
community and their ability to support more hours of programs. I think it is a good
idea for ETV also to restrict the number of hours and concern itself with quality
and not amount.
